instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.820-01512: What is 820-01512? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.ALL_SYSPWRGD: What is ALL_SYSPWRGD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYSPWRGD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_RIGHT: What is SMC_LID_RIGHT? SMC_LID_RIGHT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the right LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_RIGHT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has 20.5V (steady), but gets to 0.20A and cycles in arround 10 senconds

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> oscillates in between 12.60V and 12.28V

<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_VSW</SIGNAL> oscillates in between 5.124V and 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> oscillates in between 5.124V and 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> steady 3.3V
<SIGNAL>P3V3G3H_VSW</SIGNAL>  oscillates in between 3.3V and 3.5V

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0SW</SIGNAL>  = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V_S0SW</SIGNAL>  = 0V

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYSPWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0V

No signs of corrosion, and no short on any big coil.

Have no idea where to go from here.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
It is recognized into DFU mode?

Inspect audio board/flex for corrosion.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

It isen't recognized in DFU mode, and I have the same result with the board alone on the bench

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> coils.
Also check all big coils.
Compare readings with good board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I don't know if this error helps, but when I try to do the DFU, I always get the error "connect this mac to a thuntherbolt port"

threads.message: Did you try with the same cable used for other DFU jobs?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Yes. I've tried with 2 original cables, used before in DFU

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: T2's AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are stable?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

Not sure if are these ones. If they aren't, can you specifidy them please?

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.799V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

<SIGNAL>SOC_AWAKE_BLUE</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>SOC_AWAKE_BLUE_R</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>SOC_SLPS2R_RED</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>SOC_SLPS2R_RED_R</SIGNAL> = 0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi

L7811 = 0.837V and 0.161on diode to ground reading
L7813 = 0V and 0.356 on diode to ground reading
L7814 = 1.1V and 0.269 on diode to ground reading

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Change <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I don't have any donor board for it.

Do you know if I can find it in another board model?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
Replacing <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> worked.
TKS.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: DFU restore?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Yes, DFU restore finished without errors.

Connecting with eth cable worked, and I manage to install macOS.

TKS!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

It seams that I have other problem on this one:

When I close the display, the Mac don't hibernate.

I think that probably there is some sensor to activate it, but don't know what it is.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL>/RIGHT signals.
At least one should drop when close the lid.
<SIGNAL>IPD_LID_OPEN</SIGNAL> should drop at same time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL> is 0V, but  <SIGNAL>IPD_LID_OPEN</SIGNAL>  remains at 1.8V (read at J6700 with cable disconected)
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> is 1.8V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U4802</CHIP> is an "OR" gate, so both inputs must drop to 0V, in order to drop output too.
You have a problem with right lid sensor.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Any idea on how I can solve this?
I can´t find the LID sensor

I have no clue...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01512</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
You're right. It worked.
TKS!
